column4: Guys, bit of an urgent hand needed for gigenieks - we've unmounted his usb stick at /dev/sdb, gone to run fsck.vfat over it, and it's not opening the disk, stating there is no such volume.
what was the output of fdisk -l /dev/sdb ?
if it helps, I saw the dmesg output from when he attached the usb disk, it's definitely sdb
did you have ssh access?
no
unless I've misinterpreted the dmesg, that shows sdb as being attached with 2 partitions, sdb1 and sdb2
i think he unmounted the drive and plugged it off
- i told him only to unmount it, and then to run sudo fsck.vfat /dev/sdb to it
sdb is the raw device, this would not make sense
if there are partitions on it
we talk about gigenieks <- right?
oki
nope
it just copys stuff bytewise
you broke something?
you can rescue something if yo backupped before
what has he done with dd?
they transferred by cut and paste a folder from a source drive to external hdd, but removed the usb when ubuntu said it was finished...
the did not correctly umount the drive?
the result is that he has a reduced file on the target disk, and the file had gone from the source disk
i do not see that dd can help here
yes he did.  He umounted and removed the drive, but it came up with an error.  The buffer was still writing to the target USB disk
mmh, that seems bad luck
